correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is incidated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

div.p: CALEDONIA, the ancient name of Scotland. From the testimonies of Tacitus, Dio, and Solinus, we find that the ancient Caledonia comprehended all that country situated to the north of the rivers Forth and Clyde. In proportion as the Silures or Cimbri advanced northwards, the Caledonians, circumscribed within narrower limits, were forced to pass over into the islands which fringe the western coasts of Scotland. It is about this period, probably, that we ought to fix the first great migration of the British Gael into Ireland; that kingdom being much nearer to the promontory of Galloway and Cantyre than many of the Scottish isles are to the continent of North Britain.

To the country which the Caledonians possessed they gave the name of Gael-doch, which is the only appellation the Scots, who speak the Gaelic language, know for their own division of Britain. Gael-doch is a compound formed from Gael, the first colony of the ancient Gauls who transmigrated into Britain, and doch, a district or division of a country. The Romans, by transposing the letter l in Gael, and by softening into a Latin termination the ch of doch, formed, it is supposed, the well-known name of Caledonia.

The Creones, who inhabited the western coast of Ross, from the Volsas bay on the north to Loehduich on the south; 20. The Cerones, who inhabited the whole western coast of Inverness, and the districts of Ard-namurehan, Morvern, Sunart,and Arđgower in Argyleshire, having Loehduich on the north, and the Linne-loch on the south; and, 21. The Εpidii, who inhabited the south-west of Argyleshire, from Linne-loeh on the north, to the Frith of Clyde and the Irish Sea on the south, including Cantyre, and were bounded on the east by the country of the Albani, and by Loehfyne. Sueh, according to the best authorities, were the names and geographical positions of the twenty-one tribes whieh, at the time of the Roman invasion, oeeupied the whole of North Britain.

When the tribes of North Britain were attacked by the Romans under Agrieola (see article Britain, ehap. i.), they entered into associations, in order that, by uniting their strength, they might be more able to repel the common enemy. But the particular name of the tribe whieh either its superior power or military reputation placed at the head of the association, was the general name given by the Romans to all the confederates. Henee it is that the Moeatoe, who inhabited the districts of Scotland lying southward of the frith, and the Caledonians, who inhabited the west and north-west parts, engrossed the glory whieh belonged in eommon, though in an inferior degree, to the other tribes settled of old in North Britain.

The origin of the appellations Scoti and Picti, introduced by the later Roman authors, has occasioned mueh controversy among antiquaries in modern times. It seems tolerably certain, however, that the Scots and Piets were one and the same people; or rather, that the term Picti or Picts was the generic, and that of Scoti, or Scots, only a spécifié appellation. Eumenius the orator, who first mentions the Picts, alludes to the Caledones aliique Picti; an expression whieh implies that the Caledones and other tribes were considered as Picts. Again, with reference to the question whether the Scots were aboriginal Britons, or merely emigrants from Ireland, it has been shown by arguments whieh appear to Be invincible, that they eame originally fromIreland; but,ontheotherhand,itseemsequally eertain, that the Scots of Ireland, or the Scoticoegentes of Porphyry, a branch of the great Celtic family, passed over, at a very remote period, from the shores of Britain into Ireland, and before the beginning of the fifth eentury had given their name to the whole of that eountry. Their name, however, does not occur in the Roman annals till a. D. 360; but all the authors of the fourth century agree that Ireland was the proper country of the Seots, and that they invaded the Roman territories in North Britain about the period above mentioned. They are deseribed as an erratic or wandering race, who earned on a predatory system of warfare, and also as a transmarine people, who eame from Ireland, their native island. Under the denomination of Picts were ineluded the Caledonians and Seots, and probably also the Attaeots, a warlike elan, settled on the shores of Dumbarton and Cowal.
